data.description_suggestion: Updates an existing webhook configuration identified by its ID. Accepts a WebhookEntry object containing the webhook settings to be modified. Returns the updated webhook object with all current configuration details. This operation modifies the webhook's event subscriptions, URL endpoint, and other delivery settings. Requires authentication via HTTP Basic Auth.

data.current_description:
Get the messages related to a sent message identified by `id`.

For more information how this work, see the `relatedSentMessageId` field in the message.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve received messages related to a sent message
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves all received messages that are related to a specific sent message identified by the `id` parameter. This operation is useful for tracking message conversations and replies. Returns an array of received message objects. The relationship between messages is tracked via the `relatedSentMessageId` field in the message schema.

data.current_description:
A webhook is an URL that you can register when you want the BulkSMS system to notify you about your messages.
You can register multiple webhooks, and each one will be called.  (Note: you can also use our [Web App](https://www.bulksms.com/account/#!/advanced-settings/webhooks) to manage your webhooks interactively.)  
If you want to be notified of `SENT` messages and `RECEIVED` messages you need to create two webhooks.


### Implementing your webhook

Code samples of Webhook implementations:
* [PHP](samples/webhook-php.html)

When you implement your webhook, there are a few rules to be aware of:
- Your webhook must process `POST` requests that contains an array of messages in the post body.  This input given to your webhook has the same structure as the output produced when you call [Retrieve Messages](#tag/Message%2Fpaths%2F~1messages%2Fget).
- When you register or update your webhook, the URL will be tested by invoking it with an empty array (`[]`). 
- It is possible for your webhook to receive multiple updates for the same message and status. It happens from time to time that the mobile network duplicates status updates.
- The order by which the webhook is invoked can be unexpected.  For example, if sender A replies before sender B, your webhook might get the reply from B first.
- The webhook is expected to comply with good practices with regard to the status code it responds with.
  - A status code in the `1xx` and `2xx` range is taken as an acknowledgement that the invocation was received and that the webhook host is ready to receive another.
  - A status code in the `4xx` range is taken as a permanent problem and indicates that the webhook cannot process the message. The specific message that caused the error will be discarded, but your webhook will be invoked again when another message becomes available.
  - Any other status code will be taken as a temporary problem; and indicates that the BulkSMS system should retry. The specific message that caused the error will not be discarded and your webhook will be invoked again with this message (see the subsequent section for more details on retry processing).
- Your webhook has to respond within `30` seconds.  If no response is given in this time, the invocation will be retried.
- It is good idea to add a secret to your URL in order to make it more secure. Here is an example:
`https://www.example.com/hook.php?secret=pass763265word`
- You can use a non-standard port if necessary, for example: `https://www.example.com:8321/hook.php?secret=pass763265word`
- Your webhook can be called from a dynamic range of IP addresses, and you should be prepared to accept that the source IP can change in the future, without notice. This practice has become common with cloud-hosted solutions. If this is an insurmountable problem for your organisation, please contact support.

### Testing and troubleshooting        

Use `curl` to test your webhook.  The command below is a template that shows how the BulkSMS system invokes your code. It must return `200` for your URL before you can register it as a webhook. 

```
curl -i -X POST 'YOUR_URL_HERE' --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --header 'User-Agent: BulkSMS Invoker' --data-raw '[]'
```

When a `200` is returned for an empty array, modify the template to post multiple messages by adding JSON between the square brackets ('[]').

After your webhook is successfully registered, you can send a message to `1111111` for an end-to-end test.  The delivery to this test number will fail, but your webhook will be invoked (and there are no charges).  

### The retry process

The process the BulkSMS systems follow to handle retries is roughly the following:
- The first retry is scheduled for 90 seconds into the future.
- After the first retry, subsequent failures will have longer delays, following this sequence - 3 minutes, 6 minutes, 12 minutes thereafter the message will be retried every 15 minutes for a 2 day period.
- When all retries fail, the message will be discarded.

### Problem reports via email

Your are strongly advised to provide an email address when you register your webhook.
A notice will be sent to this email address to keep you in the loop whenever there are problems with your webhook.
In order to prevent your inbox from being flooded, the system sends a notice about an observed error no more than once in a 24 hour period.

The following emails can be expected
 - A __message retrying__ email is sent after an invocation has failed with a retry-able error.  This email is an early warning, allowing you to investigate your systems.
 - A __message discarded__ email is sent after failure email is send when a message is discarded as a consequence of a non-retry-able error.
data.description_suggestion: Registers a new webhook to receive notifications about message events. Accepts a WebhookEntry object containing the webhook URL and event type (SENT or RECEIVED). Returns the created Webhook object with a unique identifier. The webhook URL will be tested with an empty array before registration. Multiple webhooks can be registered for the same event type, and separate webhooks are required for SENT and RECEIVED event notifications. Side effects: The BulkSMS system will invoke the webhook with POST requests containing message arrays; webhook must respond within 30 seconds and return appropriate HTTP status codes (2xx for success, 4xx for permanent failure, other for retry).
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and action-oriented. Description is extensive but lacks explicit information about what is returned (the created Webhook object) and key side effects (webhook invocation behavior, response requirements, retry logic). Added clarity about the response structure and critical side effects regarding webhook invocation behavior and response handling requirements for better AI agent understanding of the operation's consequences.

These can be created via the API, by recipients replying with STOP messages, or by BulkSMS administrators. Returns a paginated collection of blocked number entries with their creation dates.

data.current_description:
Blocked numbers are phone numbers to which your account is not permitted to send messages.
The numbers can be created via this API, by a recipient replying with a STOP message to one
of your previous SENT messages, or by a BulkSMS administrator.

Sending a message to a blocked number will result in the message being assigned a status of
`FAILED.BLOCKED`. Messages sent to blocked numbers are billed to your account.
data.description_suggestion: Create a blocked number entry on your account. Blocked numbers are phone numbers to which your account is not permitted to send messages. Accepts a phone number in E.164 format. Returns the created blocked number entry. Any subsequent attempts to send messages to this number will fail with status FAILED.BLOCKED and will still be billed to your account. Note: numbers can also be blocked automatically when recipients reply with STOP messages or by BulkSMS administrators.
data.reasoning: Current description explains context but lacks input/output details and side effects. Added clarity on expected input format (E.164), what is returned, and emphasized the billing implication when messages are sent to blocked numbers. This helps AI agents understand the full consequences of the operation.

data.current_description:
Before you can use the transfer credits endpoint, the _credit-transfer facility_ must be activated for your account.  You can request activation from `support@bulksms.com`. 

The recipient must be an enabled account that uses the same currency as your account.
data.description_suggestion: Transfer SMS credits from your account to another BulkSMS account. Requires the credit-transfer facility to be activated on your account (request activation from support@bulksms.com). The recipient account must be enabled and use the same currency as your account. Accepts a TransferEntry object specifying the recipient account and credit amount. Returns confirmation of the transfer including transaction details. Credits are immediately deducted from your account and added to the recipient's account.
data.reasoning: Description lacks input/output details and side effects. Added clarity on what the operation accepts (TransferEntry schema), what it returns, and the immediate effect on both accounts. Included prerequisite information about facility activation. This helps AI agents understand when they can use this operation and what to expect.

message: Operation 'get_/messages/send' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Summary is vague ('by simple GET or POST' is not action-focused). Description lacks output details and side effects. Improved summary to be more action-oriented. Enhanced description to specify accepted parameters, return format, and clarify when to use this simplified endpoint versus the main Send Messages operation. This helps AI agents understand the operation's purpose and limitations.

data.current_summary: Send message by simple GET or POST
data.current_description:
A really simple interface for people who require a GET mechanism to submit a single message.

The URI is interpreted as UTF-8. HTTP Basic Auth is used for authentication.

__Note__ BulkSMS recommends that you use the more flexible Send Messages Operation when submitting SMS messages from your application.

Here is an example of a GET
```http
GET /v1/messages/send?to=%2b270000000&body=Hello%20World
```

You can also use the same parameters to POST form encoded fields to `/messages`.
Here is an example of a POST
```http
POST /v1/messages
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

to=%2b27000000000&body=Hello+World
```
data.summary_suggestion: Send single message via GET or POST
data.description_suggestion: Send a single SMS message using a simple GET or POST interface. Accepts query parameters: `to` (recipient phone number in E.164 format) and `body` (message text). The URI is interpreted as UTF-8. Returns a message submission response with status and message ID. This is a simplified alternative to the Send Messages operation for basic use cases. Note: BulkSMS recommends using the more flexible Send Messages operation for production applications.
data.reasoning: Summary is vague ('by simple GET or POST' is not action-focused). Description lacks output details and side effects. Improved summary to be more action-oriented. Enhanced description to specify accepted parameters, return format, and clarify when to use this simplified endpoint versus the main Send Messages operation. This helps AI agents understand the operation's purpose and limitations.

data.current_description:
Get a the message by `id`.

data.description_suggestion: Retrieve a specific message by its unique ID. Returns the complete message object including sender, recipient, body, status, submission date, and delivery information. Works for both sent (Mobile Terminating) and received (Mobile Originating) messages. Scheduled messages are available for retrieval only after their delivery date.
data.reasoning: Summary 'Show Message' is vague and not action-oriented. Description is minimal and lacks context about what is returned and message types. Improved summary to be more specific and action-focused. Enhanced description to clarify return format, message types supported, and the scheduling caveat consistent with the retrieve messages operation documentation.
